body_html:
Thank you for bringing this to our attention!
In its main computation path, TF implements atrous/dilated convolution as a sequence of
SpaceToBatch -> Regular Conv -> BatchToSpace
ops. In preparation of feeding the first SpaceToBatch op, we zero-pad the input tensor to have a size multiple of the dilation rate along the corresponding dimensions:

tensorflow/tensorflow/python/ops/nn_ops.py

Line 494 in 9d1ff68

paddings, crops = array_ops.required_space_to_batch_paddings(

By specifying a dilation rate in the ranges of [5, 10, 20, 50], you effectively end up with convolutions whose input tensor is correspondingly [5, 160], [10, 160], [20, 160], [50, 160] instead of the original/intended [1, 160], which explains the slowdown you have observed.
Not sure what is the best way to enforce that the user employs [1, dilation_rate] instead of [dilation_rate, dilation_rate]?

By specifying a dilation rate in the ranges of [5, 10, 20, 50], you effectively end up with convolutions whose input tensor is correspondingly [5, 160], [10, 160], [20, 160], [50, 160] instead of the original/intended [1, 160], which explains the slowdown you have observed.
Not sure what is the best way to enforce that the user employs [1, dilation_rate] instead of [dilation_rate, dilation_rate]?
body:
Thank you for bringing this to our attention!
In its main computation path, TF implements atrous/dilated convolution as a sequence of
SpaceToBatch -> Regular Conv -> BatchToSpace
ops. In preparation of feeding the first SpaceToBatch op, we zero-pad the input tensor to have a size multiple of the dilation rate along the corresponding dimensions:
https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/9d1ff68c97b97da3d28042751e055e296dcb007a/tensorflow/python/ops/nn_ops.py#L494
By specifying a dilation rate in the ranges of [5, 10, 20, 50], you effectively end up with convolutions whose input tensor is correspondingly [5, 160], [10, 160], [20, 160], [50, 160] instead of the original/intended [1, 160], which explains the slowdown you have observed.
Not sure what is the best way to enforce that the user employs [1, dilation_rate] instead of [dilation_rate, dilation_rate]?
